name: Code Complete
:LABEL: Curriculum
description: A dialogue about best practiecs for computer programming

name: Upstream Prerequisites and Their Impact on Construction
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain why problem definition must be clearly established before construction begins to avoid building the wrong solution;Describe how inadequate requirements specification leads to increased defects, rework, and project delays during construction;Articulate the role of software architecture as a prerequisite that defines major structural decisions before detailed construction;Identify the consequences of skipping or inadequately completing prerequisites, including increased defect rates and construction inefficiency;Given a scenario with unstable requirements, recommend specific workflow adaptations (iterative design, feature flags, modular architecture) to mitigate risk
description: Understanding upstream prerequisites and their impact on construction: Explain why problem definition must be clearly established before construction begins to avoid building the wrong solution

name: Design Challenges and Complexity Management
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Identify design as a 'wicked problem' that cannot be fully understood until it is solved, requiring iterative approaches;Explain why design involves managing complexity as the primary technical imperative in software development;Describe how design is a heuristic process with no single correct solution, requiring judgment and trade-offs;Given a design problem, produce two alternative solutions and compare their tradeoffs in terms of complexity, maintainability, and performance;Articulate why design is an emergent process that evolves through iteration and refinement rather than being fully specified upfront
description: Understanding design challenges and complexity management: Identify design as a 'wicked problem' that cannot be fully understood until it is solved, requiring iterative approaches

name: Key Design Concepts: Abstraction and Encapsulation
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define abstraction as the ability to view a programming entity from various levels of detail, focusing on essential characteristics while suppressing implementation details;Explain encapsulation as the technique of hiding implementation details behind a public interface to manage complexity;Demonstrate how abstraction allows programmers to work at the highest level of detail appropriate for a given task;Apply encapsulation principles to minimize the impact of changes by isolating implementation details from client code;Given a class or module, evaluate its interface for abstraction quality by identifying any leaked implementation details and proposing improvements
description: Understanding key design concepts: abstraction and encapsulation: Define abstraction as the ability to view a programming entity from various levels of detail, focusing on essential characteristics while suppressing implementation details

name: Information Hiding as a Design Principle
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define information hiding as concealing design decisions that are likely to change, protecting other parts of the program from those changes;Identify common secrets to hide including data structures, file formats, business rules, algorithms, and hardware dependencies;Explain how information hiding reduces the impact of changes by localizing them to single modules or classes;Apply information hiding to create barriers between areas of likely change and the rest of the system;Given a class or module design, assess what implementation details are exposed versus hidden and refactor to improve information hiding
description: Understanding information hiding as a design principle: Define information hiding as concealing design decisions that are likely to change, protecting other parts of the program from those changes

name: Working with Classes: Cohesion and Coupling
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define class cohesion as the degree to which a class's methods and data are related to a single purpose;Explain coupling as the degree of interdependence between classes, with loose coupling being desirable for maintainability;Design classes with high cohesion by ensuring all methods and data serve the class's central purpose;Minimize coupling by limiting class interfaces, avoiding deep inheritance hierarchies, and preferring composition over inheritance;Given a class design, evaluate whether the class represents a single, coherent abstraction and refactor to improve cohesion or reduce coupling
description: Understanding working with classes: cohesion and coupling: Define class cohesion as the degree to which a class's methods and data are related to a single purpose

name: High-Quality Routine Design
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define a routine as having a single, well-defined purpose that can be described without using conjunctions like 'and' or 'or';Explain functional cohesion as the strongest type of cohesion where a routine performs one and only one operation;Apply naming conventions that clearly describe what a routine does, making the code self-documenting;Identify and avoid routines with weak cohesion such as coincidental, temporal, or logical cohesion;Given a routine with poor cohesion, refactor it to improve single-responsibility and justify the changes made
description: Understanding high-quality routine design: Define a routine as having a single, well-defined purpose that can be described without using conjunctions like 'and' or 'or'

name: Pseudocode Programming Process
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Describe the pseudocode programming process as designing routines in natural language before coding in a programming language;Apply the process of writing pseudocode that describes the routine's logic at a high level of abstraction;Refine pseudocode iteratively, adding detail until it can be translated directly into code;Compare pseudocode programming with alternative approaches including test-driven development, spike solutions, and direct coding;Evaluate when pseudocode programming is most beneficial versus when alternative approaches may be more appropriate
description: Understanding pseudocode programming process: Describe the pseudocode programming process as designing routines in natural language before coding in a programming language

name: Variable Naming Conventions and Code Clarity
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Create variable names that fully and accurately describe the entity the variable represents;Optimize name length for clarity, avoiding both cryptic abbreviations and unnecessarily verbose names;Use problem-oriented names that refer to the problem domain rather than implementation details;Avoid misleading names, names with similar meanings, and names that differ only in capitalization;Follow naming conventions consistently across a codebase for variables, constants, classes, and routines using consistent domain language
description: Understanding variable naming conventions and code clarity: Create variable names that fully and accurately describe the entity the variable represents

name: Code Layout and Self-Documenting Code
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Apply consistent indentation to show logical structure and nesting levels in code;Use white space strategically to group related statements and separate unrelated ones;Write code that is clear enough to be understood without extensive comments through good naming and structure;Use comments to explain why code does something rather than what it does when the code itself is clear;Document complex algorithms, non-obvious design decisions, and workarounds with explanatory comments while avoiding redundant comments
description: Understanding code layout and self-documenting code: Apply consistent indentation to show logical structure and nesting levels in code

name: Defensive Programming Practices
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define defensive programming as protecting code from invalid inputs and unexpected conditions through validation and error handling;Implement assertions to document assumptions and catch programming errors during development;Distinguish between assertions (for catching programming errors), exceptions (for recoverable errors), and error return codes (for expected conditions);Apply input validation techniques to check preconditions, postconditions, and data invariants;Given specific error scenarios, choose between assertion, exception, or error return approaches and explain the consequences of each choice
description: Understanding defensive programming practices: Define defensive programming as protecting code from invalid inputs and unexpected conditions through validation and error handling

name: Comprehensive Testing Strategy
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Distinguish between unit tests, integration tests, contract tests, and end-to-end tests in terms of scope and purpose;Apply the test pyramid principle to balance test types, emphasizing fast unit tests with fewer slow integration tests;Design test cases that cover normal cases, boundary conditions, error conditions, and invalid inputs using arrange-act-assert structure;Implement automated unit tests that can be run repeatedly to catch regressions, using test doubles (mocks, stubs, fakes) appropriately;Write unit tests achieving comprehensive coverage of branches and paths for a given function, identifying all boundary and error cases
description: Understanding comprehensive testing strategy: Distinguish between unit tests, integration tests, contract tests, and end-to-end tests in terms of scope and purpose

name: Debugging Methodology and Techniques
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Apply the scientific method to debugging by forming hypotheses about defect causes and testing them systematically;Use debugging tools effectively including breakpoints, watch windows, and call stacks to understand program state;Stabilize errors by finding reproducible test cases before attempting to fix them;Locate defect sources by narrowing down the region of code where the defect occurs through binary search or other systematic approaches;Fix the problem not the symptom by understanding the root cause before making changes, then verify the fix resolves the issue
description: Understanding debugging methodology and techniques: Apply the scientific method to debugging by forming hypotheses about defect causes and testing them systematically

name: Refactoring for Code Quality Improvement
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define refactoring as improving code's internal structure without changing its external behavior;Identify code smells that indicate refactoring opportunities such as duplicated code, long methods, large classes, and feature envy;Apply specific refactoring techniques including Extract Method, Rename Variable, Move Method, and Replace Conditional with Polymorphism;Use automated tests to ensure refactoring does not introduce defects, running tests before and after each refactoring step;Recognize when to refactor continuously in small steps versus when to rewrite code that is fundamentally flawed
description: Understanding refactoring for code quality improvement: Define refactoring as improving code's internal structure without changing its external behavior

name: Performance Optimization Strategy
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Distinguish between performance improvement strategies: algorithm/data structure selection, system architecture, and code-level tuning;Apply the principle of optimizing at the right level: choose efficient algorithms first, then profile, then apply micro-optimizations;Identify performance bottlenecks through profiling before attempting optimizations rather than guessing;Measure performance before and after optimization to verify improvements using appropriate benchmarks;Balance performance improvements against code readability and maintainability costs, recognizing that premature optimization wastes effort
description: Understanding performance optimization strategy: Distinguish between performance improvement strategies: algorithm/data structure selection, system architecture, and code-level tuning

name: Code Review Best Practices
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define code review goals including defect detection, knowledge transfer, design quality improvement, and standards compliance;Apply systematic review checklists covering correctness, readability, tests, security, performance, and maintainability;Evaluate appropriate review size and latency to maximize effectiveness while minimizing delay;Provide constructive feedback that focuses on code rather than the author, suggesting improvements rather than just identifying problems;Given a code change, conduct a thorough review identifying issues across multiple categories and providing actionable improvement suggestions
description: Understanding code review best practices: Define code review goals including defect detection, knowledge transfer, design quality improvement, and standards compliance

name: Version Control and Pull Request Workflow
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Explain the purpose of version control for tracking changes, enabling collaboration, and maintaining code history;Apply commit hygiene practices including atomic commits, descriptive commit messages, and logical change grouping;Compare branching strategies such as trunk-based development, GitFlow, and feature branches in terms of integration frequency and merge complexity;Describe an effective pull request workflow including branch creation, review request, addressing feedback, and merge criteria;Design a branching and PR strategy appropriate for a given team size, release cadence, and risk tolerance
description: Understanding version control and pull request workflow: Explain the purpose of version control for tracking changes, enabling collaboration, and maintaining code history

name: Continuous Integration and Build Pipeline Design
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Define continuous integration as the practice of integrating and testing code changes frequently to detect integration issues early;Design a CI pipeline with appropriate stages including build, unit tests, integration tests, static analysis, and security scanning;Apply gating rules to determine which failures should block merges versus which should generate warnings;Explain the importance of reproducible builds using dependency lockfiles, versioned toolchains, and isolated build environments;Diagnose and triage CI pipeline failures systematically, distinguishing between code defects, flaky tests, and infrastructure issues
description: Understanding continuous integration and build pipeline design: Define continuous integration as the practice of integrating and testing code changes frequently to detect integration issues early

name: Secure Coding Practices
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Apply input validation and sanitization to prevent injection attacks (SQL injection, XSS, command injection);Implement secure secrets management by avoiding hardcoded credentials and using environment variables or secret stores;Apply the principle of least privilege when designing authentication and authorization mechanisms;Identify common vulnerability patterns in dependencies and apply strategies for dependency vulnerability management;Given a code scenario, identify security vulnerabilities and recommend specific secure coding patterns to address them
description: Understanding secure coding practices: Apply input validation and sanitization to prevent injection attacks (SQL injection, XSS, command injection)

name: Observability and Production Error Handling
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Implement structured logging with appropriate log levels (debug, info, warn, error) and contextual information;Design error handling strategies that include logging errors with sufficient context for diagnosis while avoiding sensitive data exposure;Explain the role of metrics, distributed tracing, and logging in understanding system behavior in production;Apply practices for creating actionable logs that enable efficient troubleshooting without excessive noise;Design an observability strategy for a service including what to log, what metrics to track, and how to correlate events across distributed systems
description: Understanding observability and production error handling: Implement structured logging with appropriate log levels (debug, info, warn, error) and contextual information

name: API Design and Interface Contracts
:LABEL: Concept
understanding_criteria: Design API interfaces with clear contracts specifying inputs, outputs, error conditions, and side effects;Apply versioning strategies to maintain backward compatibility while evolving APIs over time;Implement idempotency for operations that may be retried to prevent unintended duplicate effects;Design pagination, filtering, and sorting mechanisms for APIs that return collections;Specify appropriate timeout and retry policies with exponential backoff for resilient API interactions
description: Understanding api design and interface contracts: Design API interfaces with clear contracts specifying inputs, outputs, error conditions, and side effects
